div1.p:
During so mild a winter, the circulation
by the United States Public Health Ser-
vice of Dr. Henry R. Car-
ter's “Anti-Malarial Meas-
ures for Farmhouses and
Plantations” is exceeding-
ly timely. Last month
there were wild mosquitoes at large in New
York city, and unless weather conditions
more nearly “seasonal” ensue before the
winter's close, a month hence, an early
crop of these insects is certain. The state-
ment of Dr. Carter is direct to the point,
and in the cause of malaria there is seem-
ingly a rather difficult combination to se-
cure. The mosquito must be of certain re-
stricted kinds, it must already have bitten
some human affected with malaria and
eight to ten days must have ensued be-
tween its receiving the infection and its
ability to distribute it.

Naturally Dr. Carter turns to the preven-
tion side, for if all the individuals who have
malaria could be isolated the mosquitoes
could not bite them and in their turn would
be of no avail for disseminating the dis-
ease. The next important matter is the
draining of marshes that breed the malarial
kinds of insects, and, last, local prevention
by screening houses. Under conditions as
they exist, screening must be the sheet
anchor, for isolation would be very diffi-
cult, even if possible, while complete drain-
ing is costly. There are personal factors
like cleanliness that are of advantage in
resisting the development of malaria, but
apparently such things do not prevent in-
fection if there are infective mosquitoes
about.

Measures for prevention of breeding of
anopheles include such care or treatment
of probable breeding places as will make
them unsuitable. Draining of pools and
marshes is effective, although, if the water
is carried away in open drains, the latter
may be--in much lessened degree, however
--new breeding places. The banks of
streams should be cleared so that fish can
frequent them, and these will do yeoman
work in ridding the streams of the larvae.
If the ponds cannot be drained, coal oil
may be applied to the surface of the water.
It needs but little oil--one treatment will
last a fortnight--but it is of little use to
oil a pond with large surface or one with
grass growing in it.
